required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: New Intubation Method to Achieve Circulatory Stability and to Reduce Number of Intubation Attempts in Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: New Intubation Method to Achieve Circulatory Stability and to Reduce Number of Intubation Attempts in Neonates. A Pilot Study

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a randomized controlled pilot study investigating a new intubation method in newborn infants. In contrast to the conventional intubation method, in the new method the respirator is connected to the tube prior to insertion into the mouth (oral intubation) or into the nose (nasopharyngeal intubation). As a result, an oxygen flow is already administered via the tube during the intubation process. Heart rate, arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) and cerebral tissue oxygenation (using near-infrared spectroscopy) are recorded in both the study and control groups during intubation.
Hypothesis
- The new intubation method is safe
- The new intubation method leads to a reduction in the number of intubation attempts
- The new intubation method leads to a reduction of desaturations and bradycardia during intubation
- In the long term, it could lead to a reduction in morbidity and mortality

primary_outcome.description: Changes in the number of intubation attempts

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of intubation process in minutes

secondary_outcome.description: The number of desaturations below 80% SpO2 The number of bradycardia below 100 beats per minute (bpm), as well as the total amount of time a patient spends less than 100 bpm.

secondary_outcome.measure: Total amount of time of desaturations
secondary_outcome.description: The total amount of time in seconds a patient spends below 80% SpO2. The number of bradycardia below 100 beats per minute (bpm), as well as the total amount of time a patient spends less than 100 bpm.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 5 minutes before intubation start till 10 minutes after successful intubation
secondary_outcome.description: Using near-infrared spectroscopy to monitor changes of the cerebral tissue oxygenation

arm_group.description: In the new intubation method the respirator is connected to the tube prior to insertion into the mouth (oral intubation) or into the nose (nasopharyngeal intubation). Therefore an oxygen flow is already administered via the tube during the intubation process.

In the control group the respirator is connected to the tube and ventilation is started after the insertion of the tube into the trachea. Therefore there is no oxygen flow administered during the intubation process.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Preterm and term born neonates who are hospitalized at neonatal intensive care unit, Medical University of Graz, Austria.
- Fulfillment of indication for intubation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Malformation of the upper respiratory tract

overall_official.affiliation: Division of Neonatology, Department of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine, Medical University of Graz, Austria

facility.name: Division of Neonatology, Department of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine, Medical University of Graz
